journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A method to predict the non-linear vibratory response of bladed disc system with shrouded dampers

article-meta.aff: 1School of Energy and Power Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xian, People’s Republic of China
2State Key Lab for Mechanical Structure Strength and Vibration, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xian, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *State Key Lab for Mechanical Structure Strength and Vibration, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, 710049, People’s Republic of China. email: zlxu@mail.xjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: The prediction accuracy of the non-linear vibratory response of bladed disc system with shrouded dampers depends on the modelling of bladed disc system, the friction contact model for depicting the non-linear constraint force, and the solution method of non-linear vibration equations of the bladed disc system. In order to improve the computation efficiency, the bladed disc system is assumed to be tuned in this article. Under this assumption, the vibratory response of the bladed disc system can be predicted based on a sector model having the cyclically symmetric constraint. This article particularly describes the formulation of the sector model and the infliction of cyclically symmetric constraint. The proposed three-dimensional (3D) friction contact model used to depict the non-linear constrained force is a numerical method, in which the relative motion of the contact surfaces is an arbitrary complex periodical one. The hybrid frequency–time domain (HFT) method is applied to solve the non-linear vibration equations of the bladed disc system for its high computation efficiency and computation accuracy. Finally, based on the sector model, numerical 3D friction contact model, and HFT domain method, a method is developed to predict the non-linear vibratory response of the bladed disc system with shrouded dampers.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: High cycle fatigue due to blade vibration is an important factor in the turbine blade failure. Thus, blade designers must seek to keep the blade vibration below an acceptable level either by changing blade natural frequency to avoid the resonance vibration, or by increasing dry friction dampers to reduce theblade vibration, such as shrouded dampers. The latter approach is widely used since the shrouded dampers are very effective in suppressing the blade vibration and simple to be manufactured. However, the vibratory response prediction of the shrouded blade is not an easy task due to the inherent non-linear friction phenomena, and the complex structure of the practical turbine blade itself.

The constraint force, which occurs on contact surfaces of the dry friction dampers and comprises the tangential stick–slip friction force and normal contact force, is non-linear in nature. The development of a friction contact model to depict the constraint force has been a concern to many researchers, such as Griffin [1, 2], Menq [3–5], Yang [6–9], and Petrov [10–12]. Griffin [1, 2] first simplified the dry friction dampers as a spring–slider model with constant normal contact force experiencing one-dimensional slip motion. Menq [4] proposed a two-dimensional (2D) friction contact model in which the contact surfaces experienced 2D tangential relative motion and the normal relative motion was ignored. Yang [6, 7] proposed another 2D model in which the normal relative motion was retained, whereas the tangential relative motion degenerated into linear motion. The three-dimensional (3D) friction contact model used to depict the constraint force was first proposed by Yang and Menq [8]. In the model, the 3D relative motion of the contact surfaces was assumed to be a harmonic function, by which it can be inferred that the tangential relative motion trajectory was an ellipse and the normal contact force was a harmonic function. However, due to the complex blade shape, multimode coupled vibration, and complex excitation, the assumptions are often inaccurate in practice. The 3D friction contact model proposed in this article is a numerical method, which could compute the constraint force no matter how complex the periodical relative motion is, and thus could be used to predict the non-linear vibratory response of the real shrouded blade with arbitrary multimode coupled vibrations. Moreover, by distributing an array of the 3D friction contact models on the contact surfaces, the microslip and uneven distribution of the normal contact force due to different vibratory responses of discrete nodes on the contact surfaces are considered.

Beside the development of the friction contact model, the modelling of bladed disc is another active research area. In the previous studies, many investigators have modelled bladed disc by ignoring the disc and fixing the blade at root. Consequently, the coupling force between blade and disc, and the coupling forces between two blades due to the flexibility of the disc are ignored. The assumption that these coupling forces can be ignored is only appropriate if the disc stiffness is higher compared to the blade stiffness. If the stiffnesses of the blade and disc are comparable, the analysis used for a single blade is usually inadequate to characterize the problem. In this case, the blade and disc must be modelled as a system to investigate its non-linear vibratory response.

The computation efficiency is an important factor when predicting the non-linear vibratory response of the bladed disc system. A great reduction can be obtained by assuming that the bladed disc system is tuned, namely the random deviations among the blades caused by manufacturing tolerances, wear, and other causes are ignored. Additionally, each blade is exposed to a periodic excitation having the same amplitude but differing in phase. Under this assumption, the bladed disc system overall is a cyclically symmetric structure, and the non-linear vibratory response of the bladed disc system can be predicted based on a sector model which only comprises a blade and a disc sector. Using the sector model, the number of the vibration equations solved iteratively can be reduced to 1/Nb of that of the whole bladed disc system, where Nb is the number of blades in the bladed disc system. The cyclically symmetric constraint, which relates the displacements of one cyclically symmetric boundary of the sector model and the other cyclically symmetric boundary, is imposed on the cyclically symmetric boundaries to account for the coupling force of adjacent sectors. Petrov [13] and Siewert et al. [14, 15] have analysed the non-linear vibratory response of bladed disc system by utilizing its cyclically symmetric property.

The hybrid frequency–time (HFT) domain method [16] is applied in this article to solve the non-linear vibration equations of the bladed disc system because it could provide more accurate solutions than the harmonic balance method [17–19] and adapts to more complex non-linear constraint force. The method calculates the vibratory response in thefrequency domain, and switches to the time domain to calculate the constraint force since the constraint force in the time domain can be efficiently computed by the proposed 3D friction contact model.Using Fast Fourier Transform/Inverse Fast Fourier Transform (FFT/IFFT), the method iteratively switches back and forth between the frequency and time domains until a convergence criterion is satisfied. This method is very flexible and its key feature is the extensive use of the FFT/IFFT leading to a high computational efficiency.

sec.title: 2 VIBRATION EQUATIONS OF THE BLADED DISC SYSTEM
sec.p:
In order to accurately describe the dynamic properties of bladed disc system, the large-scale finite element (FE) model of the bladed disc system is used in the non-linear vibratory response analysis. Figure 1 gives the FE mesh of a bladed disc system which comprises millions of degrees of freedom (DOFs). It is usually impossible to calculate the non-linear vibratory response of the whole bladed disc system because of the high requirements of computer storage and cost. However, a great reduction can be obtained by assuming that the bladed disc system is cyclically symmetric structure. It means that each blade has same dynamic properties, and each bladeis exposed to a periodic excitation having the same amplitude but differing in a phase. As a result, the non-linear vibratory response of the bladed disc system can be predicted based on the sector model which only comprises a blade and a disc sector. The coupling force between two adjacent sectors can be reflected by inflicting the cyclically symmetric constraint on a pair of cyclically symmetric boundaries, where the considered sector model interacts with the neighboring sector models. Fig. 1
FE mesh of a bladed disc system

sec.title: 2.1 Sector model
sec.p:
On the assumption that the bladed disc system is cyclically symmetric structure, the non-linear vibratory response of the whole bladed disc system can be predicted based on the sector model having the cyclically symmetric constraint. Figure 2 gives the FE mesh of the sector model. The vibration equation of the sector model can be formulated as (1) where
where M, C, and K are the mass, damping, and stiffness matrices of the sector model, respectively. The displacement vector,u(t) are, can be divided into five segments, ubr(t) and ubl(t) are, respectively, the displacement vectors of DOFs on the right and left cyclically symmetric boundaries, usr(t) and usl(t) are, respectively, the displacement vectors of DOFs on the right and left contact surfaces of shrouded damper, um(t) is the displacement vector of all the other DOFs, f(t) is a vector of excitation, fs(t,usr(t),usl(t)) is a vector of non-linear constraint force in which fsr(t,usr(t),usl(t)) and fsl(t,usr(t),usl(t)) are, respectively, the non-linear constraint forces occurring on the right and left contact surfaces of shrouded damper, and fb(t,ubr(t),ubl(t)) is a vector of linear coupling force in which fbr(t,ubr(t),ubl(t)) and fbl(t,ubr(t),ubl(t))are,respectively, the linear coupling forces of the considered sector and sectors adjacent to it from the right and left. These linear coupling forces are dependent on the relative displacements of the considered sector and its adjacent sectors. Fig. 2
FE mesh of the sector model

sec.title: 2.2 Cyclically symmetric constraint
sec.p: As mentioned above, the coupling force between twoadjacent sectors is reflected by imposing the cyclically symmetric constraint on the right and left cyclically symmetric boundaries. If the number of DOFs on the right cyclically symmetric boundary is identical to that on the left cyclically symmetric boundary, the displacement vectors and coupling forces of the left and right cyclically symmetric boundaries can be related by (2) (3) where h is the engine order of the excitation and φ is the interblade phase angle which is defined as (4) where Nb is the number of blades in the bladed disc system. The displacement vector, u(t), can be transformed in an abbreviated form (5)

By substituting equations (3) and (5) into equation (1), the vibration equation of the sector model becomes (6) where M~=T¯MT, C~=T¯CT, K~=T¯KT, f~s(t,usr(t),usl(t))=T¯fs(t,usr(t),usl(t)), f~(t)=T¯f(t), and

It is clear that the matrices M~,C~, and K~ are in the Hermitian form due to the infliction of the cyclically symmetry constraint. Thus, the eigenvalues of the sector model are real, but the eigenvectors are complex. The total number of DOFs present in equation (1) may now be reduced by the number of DOFs on a right cyclically symmetric boundary. The vectors of the unknown coupling forces of the left and right cyclically symmetric boundaries are eliminated during this transformation process.

sec.title: 3 FORMULATION OF THE CONSTRAINT FORCE
sec.p: During the engine operation, the shrouded blades rotate through the fluid flow with severe fluctuation, and as a result, the blades may bend and twist due to their complex shape. The bended and twisty blade vibrations lead to a condition in which the constraint force occurring on the contact surfaces is 3D. Moreover, the constraint force is non-linear in nature since (1) the normal contact force which is the normal direction component of the constraint force is unilateral, namely compression force can be acted at the contact surfaces but tension force is not allowed; (2) the tangential friction force which is the tangential direction component of the constraint force has inherent non-linear characteristics.

The 3D friction contact model proposed in this article is a numerical method, which is the extension of Sanliturk and Ewins’s 2D friction contact model [20]. In the proposed model, the constraint force is simulated by an array of 3D spring–slider contact pairs which are evenly distributed on the contact surfaces and represented by the black dots in Fig. 3. It should be noted that the kinetic state of each contact pair is determined in an iterative calculation process. Therefore, these contact pairs have different kinetic states. At some time instant, some contact pairs are sticking, some contact pairs slipping, and others separating. Meanwhile, these contact pairs depend on each other, and still affect each other. The contact area varies during one vibration period, which can also be simulated by iteratively computing the kinetic states of these contact pairs. Fig. 3
FE mesh of the shrouded blade

sec.title: 3.1 THE 3D FRICTION CONTACT MODEL
sec.p:
To compute the constraint force, the 3D relative motion of the contact surfaces is decomposed into a tangential component along the contact surfaces and a normal component perpendicular to the contact surfaces. The tangential component induces the stick–slip friction force, which dissipates the blade vibration energy and attenuates the blade vibration to a safety level. The normal component causes the variation of the normal contact force and possible separation of the contact surfaces. Figure 4 gives the3D friction contact model in which, to easily understand, only one 3D spring–slider contact pair is given. The constraint force is simulated by the contact pair, which comprises two sliders (points A and B) and two springs (Kt and kn). Surfaces 1 and 2 are the mating contact surfaces which belong to the adjacent blades, respectively. Point A adheres to surface 1 and remains static relative to surface 1 at all time. The trajectory of point A is the same as surface 1 which could be obtained by solving the blade vibration equation. Point B is in contact with surface 2 and undergoes stick–slip motion along surface 2 when surface 1 is in motion relative to surface 2. When the normal relative motion becomes large, point B may experience temporary separation from surface 2. By tracing the trajectory of point B in several periods of motion, the stabilized trajectory of point B can be obtained. The stiffness of the contact pair is characterized by the two linear springs, Kt and kn, which, respectively, represent the shear and normal stiffness of the contact surfaces. In order to consider the anisotropy of the contact surfaces for different manufacture and finishing treatments, the tangential stiffness Kt is defined as follows (7) Fig. 4
The 3D friction contact model

The tangential stiffness matrix Kt could be a symmetric matrix, or an asymmetric matrix, which depends on the parameters of the contact surfaces. Moreover, the static friction coefficient, μs, and dynamic friction coefficient, μd, are different in this model.

A local coordinate system xyz is established on surface 2, in which thex and y axes are coincident with the tangential directions of surface 2 as seen in Fig. 4, and the z axis is coincident with the normal direction.The trajectories of points A and B in the xyz coordinate system can be described as xk A, yk A, zk A(k=1,2,…,n) and xk B, yk B, zk B(k=1,2,…,n), respectively, where n is the number of discrete points in one period of motion. The normal contact force, which depends on the normal relative displacement and initial normal load,n0, can be expressed as (8)
The friction force in one period of motion can be represented by a vector (9)

Before the friction force is obtained, the model needs to compute the trajectory of point B on the contact surfaces. The trajectory of point B depends on the normal contact force and the relative motion of surface 1 to surface 2. The tangential tension force between points A and B in one period of motion can be expressed as (10) where
At some time instant tk, if the tension force, Tk, remains less than the static friction force, μsfz k, point B remains stationary relative to surface 2. However, if point A moves away from point B and the tension force exceeds the static friction, point B is moving towards point A until the tension force equals to the dynamic friction μd fz k. If the normal relative motion of surfaces 1 and 2 becomes large, and the normal contact force fz k equals zero, the trajectories of points A and B will coincide and the tension force Tk will be equal to zero. For a given complex motion of point A, the stabile trajectory of point B can be obtained by numerically tracing the position of point B. The detailed procedure of computing the trajectory of point B can be found in the study of Gu and Xu [21]. Figure 5 shows the trajectories of points Aand B as well as the direction of the friction force in one period of motion, in which, to easily understand the trajectory of point A is supposed as an ellipse. When the trajectory of point B is obtained, the friction force in one period of motion can be expressed as (11) Fig. 5
Trajectory of the friction contact pair

sec.title: 3.2 Relative displacement of the contact surfaces
sec.p:
As mentioned above, the non-linear constraint force depends on the relative displacement of the mating contact surfaces. Since the bladed disc system is assumed tuned, the condition of cyclically symmetry can be utilized when calculating the relative displacement of the mating contact surfaces. Figure 6 shows the schematic of the bladed disc assembly. In the figure, the displacements of DOFs on the right and left contact surfaces of the j − 1th, jth, and j + 1th shrouded blade are, respectively, defined as
and
Based on the tuned system assumption, the relationships between the displacements of DOFs on the contact surfaces of the neighboring blades can be formulated as (12) (13) Fig. 6
FE mesh of the bladed disc assembly

Therefore, the relative displacements of DOFs on the right and left contact surfaces of the jth shrouded blade can be derived as (14) (15) where dsr j (t) denotes the relative displacements of DOFs on the right contact surface of the jth shrouded blade and dsl j (t) denotes the relative displacements of DOFs on the left contact surface of the jth shrouded blade. The relationships given by equations (14) and (15) allow the relative displacements of DOFs on the right and left contact surfaces of the jth shrouded blade can be expressed in terms of its own displacements only. Consequently, the constraint force can be related to displacement of the jth shrouded blade only, and then it is possible to base on the sector model to predict the non-linear vibratory response of the whole bladed disc system. From equations (14) and (15), the relative displacements of the right and left contact surfaces of the jth shrouded blade can be related as (16)

It is worth noting that only the relative displacements of DOFs on the left contact surface need be derived since the relative displacements of DOFs on the right contact surface can be determined by equation (16). Moreover, the relative displacements, dsr j (t) and dsl j (t), are also periodic since usr j-1(t),usr j (t), usl j (t), andusl j+1(t) are periodic.

sec.title: 4 HFT METHOD
sec.p: The HFT method employs the advantages of both the frequency and time domains. It calculates the vibratory response of bladed disc system in the frequency domain because the vibration equations of bladed disc system forming in the frequency domain (which are non-linear algebraic equations) are easily solved than the vibration equations forming in the time domain (which are non-linear differential equations). Meanwhile, it calculates the constraint force inthe time domain because the constraint force is non-linear function of the past and present motion states of bladed disc system and can be accurately calculated in the time domain by the proposed 3D friction contact model. FFT/IFFT are applied in the method to switch back and forth between the frequency and time domains, since it makes the computation time of the HFT method reasonable, especially in obtaining steady-state vibratory responses.

Taking FFT to both sides of equation (6) yields (17) (18) (19) where U~(ωk), F~(ωk), and F~s(ωk,U~(ωk)) are the transforms of u~(t), f~(t), and f~s(t,usr(t),usl(t)), respectively, ωk is the discrete frequency, H(ωk) is the frequency response function whose components are functions of ωk, ΔT is the sampling period, and N is the number of samples in the FFT of each sampling period. equation (17) is a non-linear algebraic equation which needs to be iteratively and simultaneously solved. Since large-scale FE model of the sector model has been used, the associated computation time for solving equation (17) will be prohibitively high. Moreover, the extreme large memory requirements for data storage make it unfeasible to directly solve equation (17).

It should be noted that except for the elements associated with those DOFs on the contact surfaces, the other elements of F~s(ωk,U~(ωk)) are zeros. Using the modal analysis, the natural frequencies and the associated mode shapes of the sector model can be obtained. The pth natural frequency and corresponding normalized mode shape are denoted as ωp and υp, respectively. Hence, the vibration equations of the sector model can be transformed into the modal domain. The displacement vector, U~(ωk), can be replaced by the modal coordinate vector, U¯p(ωk). (20) (21) (22) where U¯p(ωk) is the vibratory response corresponding to the p th mode, U∧p(ωk) is the vibratory response due to the excitation, Θkp is the receptance matrix corresponding to the p th mode, ζp is the modal damping ratio corresponding to the pth mode, and P is the number of the modes that is kept. Since the constraint force only depends on the relative displacements of DOFs on the contact surfaces, the scale of equations iteratively solved can be reduced. Suppose that the number of the DOFs on the contact surfaces is L and these DOFs are the anterior DOFs of the sector model, the vibratory response of DOFs on the contact surfaces can be represented as follows (23) (24) where U~l (ωk) is the vibratory response of the lth DOFs on the contact surfaces corresponding to the p th mode, U∧p l (ωk) is the vibratory response due to the excitation, and Θkp l is the lth row of Θkp. The number of equations in equations (23) and (24) is tinier than equations (20) and (21); then, the constraint force, F~s(ωk,U~(ωk)), can be efficiently computed. Once the constraint force is obtained, the vibratory responses of the bladed disc system can be obtained by solving equations (20) to (22) directly.

Equations (23) and (24) are non-linear algebraic equations which need to be iteratively solved. Begin with an initial estimate of the solution, (U~l(ωk))0, which is transformed into the time domain by IFFT to provide the vibratory response in the time domain, (u~l(t))0. With (u~l(t))0 known, the constraint force in the time domain,(f~s(t,usr(t),usl(t)))0, can be calculated by the proposed 3D friction contact model. Also,then, using FFT, the constraint force can betransformed from the time domain to frequency domain:(f~s(t,usr(t),usl(t)))0→(F~s(ωk,U~(ωk)))0. Since (F~s(ωk,U~(ωk)))0 is known in terms of its frequency components, equations (23) and (24) can be solved for the next estimate of the frequency domain response, (U~l(ωk))1. This procedure forms a complete iteration of the HFT method and can be seen in Fig. 7. Repeat the procedure until an appropriate convergence criterion is satisfied. Three kinds of iterative methods and different initial estimates of the solution are used to solve the non-linear equations. The iterative methods are direct iteration, Newton–Raphson method, and Monte Carlo method, respectively. The initial estimates may be obtained from the linear vibratory response when ignoring the constraint force, or from a known solution corresponding to a closely related state. A relative convergence check tests how much the blade vibratory responses are changing from iteration to iteration. Convergence is achieved when the relative change in each component is less than 0.001. Fig. 7
Procedure of the HFT method

sec.title: 5 VIBRATORY RESPONSE OF THE BLADED DISC SYSTEM
sec.p: Based on the sector model, numerical 3D friction contact model and HFT method, the non-linear vibratory responses of a real bladed disc system are analysed. Fig. 2 gives the FE mesh of the sector model which comprises 15,265 nodes and 65,151 tetrahedral 10-node elements. The first two natural frequencies (ω1, ω2) of the bladed disc system are 121.61 and 165.67 Hz, respectively. The blade elastic modulus E=2.0×1011 N/m, density ρ=7800 kg/m3, and Poisson ratio υ=0.3. The harmonic excitations are applied near the blade tip and the excitations are: qx(t)=10sinωt and qy(t)=10cosωt. The parameters of the shrouded damper are: μs=0.3, μd=0.28, kxx=kyy, and kxy=kyx=kyy/2. The excitation engine order, h=1, the number of modes, P=5, and the number of samples in the FFT of each sampling period, N=64. The dimensionless frequency ω¯ is defined as ω¯=ω/2πω1 and the vibratory responses of the blade tip are given in this section.

Under four different initial normal loads, the x and y axes direction friction forces in one period of motion are given in Figs 8 and 9, respectively. The corresponding hysteresis curves are given in Figs 10 and 11, respectively. The y axis direction friction force is bigger than the x axis direction friction force because the shrouded blade vibration is mainly along y axis direction in this situation. These hysteresis curves are looped in the clockwise direction, and consist of four alternating stick and slip regions except for small initial normal load case, where the contact surfaces will separate for a while during one period of motion. Under two different initial normal loads, the vibratory responses of the blade tip versus the orders of the discrete frequencies are given in Figs 12 and 13, respectively. The horizontal axis, k, is the subscript of the discrete frequency, ωk, which denotes the orders of the discrete frequencies. It can be seen that the vibratory response corresponding to ω1 is extraordinarily bigger than others since the single harmonic excitation is applied in this situation. Fig. 8
The x axis direction friction forces in one period of motion (1: n0=1N, 2: n0=3N, 3: n0=5N, and 4: n0=8N) Fig. 9
The y axis direction friction forces in one period of motion (1: n0=1N, 2: n0=3N, 3: n0=5N, and 4: n0=8N) Fig. 10
Hysteresis curves of the x direction friction force Fig. 11
Hysteresis curves of the y direction friction force Fig. 12
Vibratory responses versus the orders of the discrete frequencies (ω¯=0.8, N0=1N) Fig. 13
Vibratory responses versus the orders of the discrete frequencies (ω¯=0.8, N0=5N)

Under different initial normal loads, the vibratory responses of the blade tip near the first two natural frequencies of the bladed disc system are given in Figs 14 and 15, respectively. In these figures, the vibratory responses are the synthesized vibratory responses of the three directions. It can be seen that the resonance frequencies increase with the initial normal load n0 and the resonance responses are bounded within two extreme cases: fully separate and fully stick cases. The fully separate case occurs when the initial gap of the contact surfaces is big and therefore the contact surfaces are separate all the time. In this case, the constraint force does not exist and the bladed disc is a linear system. The fully stick case occurs when the initial normal load is high and the contact surfaces are fully stick all the time. In this case, the contact surfaces do not dissipate energy at all. Between the two extreme cases, there exists an optimal initial normal load under which the vibratory responses are minimized. Fig. 14
Vibratory responses of the bladed disc system (1: fully separate, 2: n0=1N, 3: n0=5N, 4: n0=10N, 5: n0=15N, 6: n0=20N, and 7: fully stick) Fig. 15
Vibratory responses of the bladed disc system (1: fully separate, 2: n0=1N, 3: n0=5N, 4: n0=10N, 5: n0=15N, and 6: fully stick)

Around the first natural frequency of the bladed disc system, the relationships of resonant response amplitudes versus the initial normal loads with different contact stiffnesses are given in Fig. 16. It can be seen that the resonant response amplitudes have the same variable tendency: the resonant response amplitudes decrease with the increase of the initial normal loads till the optimal initial normal loads are reached; exceeding the optimal initial normal loads, the resonant response amplitudes increase with the initial normal loads till the stick states are reached, and then the resonant response amplitudes maintain a constant value. On the whole, the resonant response amplitudes decrease with the increase of the tangential stiffness. The relationships of resonant frequency versus the initial normal load around the first natural frequency are given in Fig. 17. Fig. 16
Resonant amplitudes versus initial normal loads (1: kxx=1500 N/mm, 2: kxx=1000 N/mm, and3: kxx=500 N/mm) Fig. 17
Resonant frequencies versus initial normal loads (1: kxx=1500 N/mm, 2: kxx=1000 N/mm, and3: kxx=500 N/mm)

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The computation efficiency is an important factor when predicting the non-linear vibratory response of bladed disc system with shrouded dampers. Agreat reduction can be obtained by assuming that the bladed disc system is tuned. Under this assumption, the vibratory response of the bladed disc system can be predicted based on a sector model having the cyclically symmetric constraint. This article particularly describes the development of the sector model and the infliction of cyclically symmetric constraint. Based on the sector model, numerical 3D friction contact model, and HFT method, a method for predicting the non-linear vibratory response of bladed disc system with shrouded dampers is developed. The method could predict the non-linear vibratory response of real bladed disc because large-scale FE modelling of the bladed disc which accurately allows its dynamic properties is used. Moreover, the method could predict more complex non-linear vibratory response of bladed disc system because the numerical 3D friction contact model could describe the complex constraint force and the HFT method could take into account the multiple harmonic components of vibratory response. Finally, based on the proposed method, the non-linear vibratory responses of a real bladed disc system are predicted.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: The authors acknowledge the financial support from National Natural Science Foundation of China through grant no. 50675169 and National High Technology Research and Development Program ofChina (863 program) through grant no. 2007AA04Z1A1.
